subject: New Perl Mongers in Karlsruhe amd Perl Oasis conference in Orlando
header: Welcome to 2013! Let's start this year with a new Perl Monger group in Germany meeting on th 9th January and annual Perl Oasis conference in Orlando, Florida that will be held between 11-13 January.

In another note, as Yanick is getting more involved in the creation of the Perl Weekly, I (Gabor) might need to start changing the way I write. For example should I start refering to myself in the third person? Or maybe we should each make it clear who is talking in the comments. This latter sounds more personal. For now, I'll add this sig. to some of the entries. What do you think? ~ Gabor

entries.title: A wake-up call for WxPerl
entries.text: Just as 2012 ended Steve Cookson kicked off a thread with an emotional mail about the future of WxPerl, the Perl binding of the wxWidgets toolkit. Many people jumped on the thread. Some pessimistic, some optimistic. In any case, there seem to be some momentum for movement, so if writing desktop applications is your thing, then look at the thread, how you might get involved.

entries.desc: Too often, peeps eschew test descriptions in TAP suites. Ovid explains why this is sub-optimal, and how those descriptions can be leveraged to make tests as self-documenting as possible.
entries.title: How to write a test description
DBI 1.623 was released
entries.text: Tim Bunce has announced the new released of the Database independent interface of Perl. See the list of bug fixes.

entries.desc: The mechanics of Git::CPAN::Patch got a major tune-up. Net result for users? Faster, much faster cloning.
entries.title: Git::CPAN::Patch -- Now with MetaCPAN Power!

entries.desc: Assumptions. Everyone knows what they make out of you and me. Well, rejoice, for David Wheeler announced that a new version of Sqitch is out, introducing a 'verify' command that will help to confirm that was supposed to be deployed really has been deployed.
entries.title: Sqitch: Trust, But Verify

entries.desc: New year, new release of DBD::Oracle. No new features this time around, but a fair amount of bug fixing.
entries.title: DBD::Oracle v1.54 on its way to CPAN

entries.desc: Ever cringed as you saw passwords being written in log files? Steffen Müller showcases Store::Opaque as a tool to use to ensure that this doesn't happen.
entries.title: Protect Against Accidental Logging of Sensitive Information

entries.desc: Pinto is a very nice tool to create and manage local Perl module repositories. Yanick investigates an alternate way of using it within a Dancer app to create a CPAN proxy.
entries.title: Picking Packages With Pass-through, Proxied Pinto
Early Stratopan
entries.text: Stratopan is a web based service providing the features of Pinto. Without installing Pinto.

entries.title: News of Gitpan's demise might have been exagerated...
entries.text: Something under Gitpan's ashes is moving... Want to accelerate the rebirth of that particulary shiny phoenix? Then hop to the Gitpan wiki, and see what you can help up with!

entries.title: deb.perl.it - bridging CPAN and Debian, step1
entries.text: What to know which packages are bundled in Debian? Lucky you, Jozef created a brand-new website to bridge CPAN and the Debian repository.

entries.text: I think this is the first time I see a detailed annual report from The Perl Foundation. It is much needed. Thank you Dan Wright!. (And to be true to my never satisfied self, I'd like to see an even more detailed report regarding the sources of money and the actual spending. Which grant received how much etc.) ~ Gabor

entries.title: Karlsruhe Perl Mongers
entries.text: The first meeting of the Karlsruhe Perl Mongers will take place on 9 January 2013. Check out the German Perl Monger site for details.

entries.title: How to convince Meta CPAN to show a link to the version control system of a distribution?
entries.text: Last week I showed how to add the license field to the CPAN distributions. This time it is about the link to the version control reposiotry. Apparently only about 50% of the distributions on CPAN have this information. I think it would be nice to increase that percentage. That might make it easier for people to contribute some fixes.

entries.title: Abstraction Levels
entries.text: How do you decide on the abstraction level when you design your API? fREW Schmidt asked. Do you let people override your methods or do you just create functions? When do you need to allow subclassing and when is that an overkill?
